name: comp
content:
comp verb
(GIVE FREE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ I or T ] mainly US to give goods or services to someone without asking for payment: Usually, the writer's entire trip is comped. They comped us two tickets. Bar staff are checked to make sure they don't comp too much. comped meals/drinks
[ I or T ] mainly US to allow someone to do something without having to pay: You can comp two guests.
More examplesFewer examplesThey complained about slow service and the restaurant ended up comping them their desserts and drinks. If you eat in one of the restaurants at the mall the $15 parking charge is comped. Casinos are generally comping less now, and only for high-roller slots players.

comp verb
(ENTER COMPETITIONS)
UK to regularly enter competitions, for example in magazines or on the internet, in order to win prizes: It takes a bit of organization but there are people who make a living by comping.
More examplesFewer examplesI have been comping for over a decade and this is the biggest prize I've ever won.

comp noun [C]
(SCHOOL)
UK a school in the UK for children above the age of 11 of all abilities. Comp is short for
comprehensive school : He went to the local comp. She works at one of the toughest inner-city comps in the country.
More examplesFewer examplesThe local comp is a very good school.Is it a comp or a grammar school?Most of the kids at Cottoncroft Comp have part-time jobs.

comp noun [C]
(COMPENSATION)
business
  US informal the money that an employee receives for doing their job, sometimes including other benefits (= rewards). Comp is short for compensation: What's the comp you're offering for that position? We need to put together a comp package that will attract a highly successful candidate.
More examplesFewer examplesAverage comp at this top firm is estimated at $700,000.A study has found that comp rates do not affect the economy.Motivation can be improved by comp structures.
